The report was prepared by B. Purdue and S. Zaidansyah.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Indonesia is endeavoring to recover from the Asian financial crisis by addressing, among 
others, endemic issues of weak governance, in particular, the weakness of the legal and judicial 
system, which has affected enforcement of rule of law. The Government recognizes this and in 
its 1999–2004 Guidelines for State Policy, indicated that one of its five national objectives is to 
achieve rule of law.1 As a part of its overall support to strengthen governance in Indonesia, 
Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) 2003–2005 country and strategy program for Indonesia has 
identified legal and judicial reform as a primary focus area. To support the effort, ADB has 
prepared this technical assistance (TA) to assist in the improvement of judicial administration. 
The Fact-Finding Mission for this TA was fielded in two phases: 1–3 September 2003 and 9–15 
October 2003. The Mission was able to reach an understanding with the Government and the 
Supreme Court on the purpose and output, key activities and methodologies, cost estimates 
and financing, implementing arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services of the 
TA.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.    Reforms in the judiciary have received momentum through the implementation of Law 
35/1999, which stipulates that by the end of August 2004, the administrative responsibilities of 
the lower branches of the judiciary, which are currently in the hands of the executive branch, will 
be transferred to the Supreme Court. This, upon implementation, will place the Supreme Court 
at the center of judicial administration in Indonesia. 
 
3.  To  position  itself  for  this  increased  role,  the  Supreme  Court  commissioned  the 
formulation of several “blueprints” for its own reforms and that of other aspects of the judiciary.3 
The International Monetary Fund (IMF), in collaboration with the Netherlands, financed four 
blueprints: (i) an academic draft and bill on the judicial commission, (ii) the policy paper on 
judicial  personnel  management  reform,  (iii)  the  policy  paper  on  the  court’s  financial 
management reform, and (iv) the policy paper on permanent judicial education system reform.  
A fifth blueprint, supported by the Partnership for Governance Reform, pertains to  Supreme 
Court reform. The blueprints are the first of their kind to be conducted through a collaborative 
working relationship between the Supreme Court and local civil society, with a special focus on 
judicial reform.4 A steering committee will be established by the Supreme Court to implement 
the blueprints. The donor community, led by IMF, is also collaborating with the Supreme Court 
to implement the reforms recommended in the blueprints. The TA aims to adopt some of the 
recommendations of the blueprint on the reform of the Supreme Court and the policy paper on 
permanent  judicial  education  system  reform.  The  Supreme  Court  has  requested  ADB’s 
assistance to help resolve case management issues. The TA has been developed in close 
collaboration with the aid agencies and complements the role of other aid agencies. The 
Supreme Court, which will have a substantially increased role by the end of August 2004, will be 
the Executing Agency for the TA.

4.   Several significant problems in case management have been identified at the Supreme 
Court. Such problems are manifest at all stages of the process of litigation at the court, from the 
time a case is registered until the judgment is disseminated to the litigants.5 For example, 
litigants may be able to gain registration of cases dated prior to their actual submission and, due 
to a lack of transparency, this may go unnoticed. Therefore, the flow of cases in the Supreme 
Court must be made far more transparent. The Supreme Court has created systems, such as 
Akses-121 or Sistem Informasi Mahkamah Agung Republik Indonesia (SIMARI-the Information 
System of the Supreme Court), that attempt to allow the public to track cases; however, the 
systems have at least two problems. First, they are only in the Supreme Court, so that litigants 
have to be physically present in the Supreme Court to track the status of a case. Second, the 
systems do not provide sufficient information on the actual stage of the case-flow (footnote 5, 
pp. 130-132).  Therefore, an effective case tracking system, which is easily accessible and 
provides more comprehensive information, should be created to allow for greater transparency. 
Such transparency could, in turn, create better accountability and lead to greater predictability in 
the management of cases in the Supreme Court. The establishment of a new system should 
use the current resources available in the Supreme Court.   
 
5.  In line with the need to increase transparency in the Supreme Court, the public should 
also  be  provided  with  greater  access  to  previous  judgments.  Presently,  Supreme  Court 
judgments are only available through certain publications, which are limited in circulation and 
cover only a small number of cases. A mechanism is needed to allow for greater public 
dissemination of judgments issued by the Supreme Court (footnote 5, p. 136). Therefore, the TA 
will conduct a study on the best mechanism to facilitate dissemination of Supreme Court 
judgments to the public. The TA will also prepare a draft decree to be issued by the chief justice 
of the Supreme Court on the requirement for the dissemination of judgments to the public. The 
draft decree will include implementing guidelines, which will take into account the findings of the 
feasibility study.  
 
6.  The other problem found in the Supreme Court is the inconsistency of judgments issued, 
even where similar points of law are being decided. There are several causes for this, such as 
(i) the Indonesian legal system not adhering to the principle of binding precedent, (ii) the lack of 
access by the Supreme Court judges to cases with similar points of law, and (iii) the absence of 
an effective chamber system. Addressing item (i) would require involvement of legislative action 
beyond  the  Supreme  Court’s  mandate.  However,  it  can  mitigate  the  other  causes  of 
inconsistency by creating an effective case distribution system.  
 
7.  To have a proper case distribution mechanism, a proper case classification system is 
needed first. The classification of cases could be based on (i) the similarity of the legal issues 
involved, or (ii) level of difficulty of the cases (footnote 5, pp. 92-93). Once a proper case 
classification system has been established, using the appropriate information technology (IT), 
the Supreme Court could establish a data base on previous judgments it has issued.6 The data 
base should be easily accessible by each Supreme Court judge (and assistants) to enable them 
to examine cases in a more expeditious manner. Such an IT system must be complemented 
with a proper chamber system.7 This TA will also study what is the most effective chamber 
system for the Indonesian Supreme Court.

8.  Many of the Supreme Court judges consider that the lack of effective case management 
contributes to the massive backlog of cases in the Supreme Court (footnote 5, p.17), (currently 
estimated at 16,000 cases).8  
 
9.    To obtain the results intended under the TA, Supreme Court administrative personnel 
need adequate training. They have had some training, but it has not been adequately focused 
and better qualified instructors are needed. One of the blueprints suggested that the training 
should focus on improving the skills required for the performance of the duties and work of the 
court administrative personnel.9 The proposed TA will develop and implement such capacity 
building programs for the Supreme Court.  
 
10.  By  the end of August 2004, the Supreme Court will have increased administrative 
powers over the lower branches of the judiciary. This will allow the TA’s outputs to be replicated, 
where applicable, to improve the administration of lower courts.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The TA is aimed at strengthening the administration of the Supreme Court, as the apex 
body of the court system. Institutional strengthening will facilitate the reforms at the Supreme 
Court and eventually throughout the judiciary.     
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.   The TA will include the following components:  
 
(i)  Case  management  in  the  Supreme  Court.  This  component  includes  the 
following subcomponents:  
 
a.  Improvement  of  the  case  administration.  The  output  from  this 
subcomponent  will  be  an  improved  case-tracking  mechanism  in  the 
Supreme Court. 
 
b.  Effective public dissemination of Supreme Court judgments.  The 
initial output from this subcomponent will be a feasibility study conducted 
to determine, under local circumstances, the best mechanism for the 
dissemination of Supreme Court judgments. Based on this study, the TA 
will  prepare  a  draft  decree,  to  be  issued  by  the  chief  justice  of  the 
Supreme Court, on the requirement for public access to judgments issued 
by the Supreme Court. The decree will be accompanied by guidelines on 
its implementation.  
 
                                                                                                                                                             
various chambers are not strictly specialized according to the different areas of laws. Therefore, each chamber may 
examine a range of cases.

Jakarta.  
9 Supreme Court of the Republic of Indonesia. 2003. Policy Paper on Permanent Education and Training System for

c.  Facilitation of the production of consistent judgments.  The initial 
output from this subcomponent will be the establishment of a new case 
classification system to improve the case distribution system. The new 
case classification system will include sex-disaggregated information and 
gender-based cases. Using the case classification system, an automated 
data base, accessible to the Supreme Court judges (and assistants), on 
previous judgments issued by the Supreme Court will be established. In 
addition, a study will be made of the most effective chamber system for 
the Supreme Court.  
 
(ii)  Capacity  building  for  Supreme  Court  administration  personnel.  It  is 
expected  that  the  training  will  improve  the  capacity  of  the  Supreme  Court 
administrative  personnel  to  manage  cases.  Since  the  output  of  the  case 
management component of the TA will increase automation in the court, the 
training will include the training on the  use of IT and its application to judicial 
administration.  The  training  will  be  provided  equally  to  male  and  female 
administrative staff and will use a “training-of-trainers” approach. The aim of this 
component is to prepare staff for the administration of a more automated court 
system. 
 
13.  The TA will use IT solutions to improve systems and procedures. The TA is designed to 
upgrade existing resources, where possible, rather than create new or overlapping resources. 
The  first  component  will  emphasize  transparency  in  the  judicial  process.  The  increasing 
transparency in the judicial process will contribute to the reduction of corruption, which, in turn, 
will allow for greater predictability in the judicial process. The second component will provide the 
necessary training for the personnel to be able implement effectively the output of the first 
component. Both components will be implemented simultaneously.  The TA framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent, of which $310,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $315,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent covering the total foreign exchange cost and 
$190,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance the balance of the local currency cost 
of  $125,000 equivalent to finance counterpart staff, office facilities, and workshops. Details of 
the cost estimates are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.   The Supreme Court will be the Executing Agency. The Supreme Court will appoint a TA 
manager, ideally a second-echelon official in the Supreme Court with considerable experience 
in case management.  The manager will coordinate the day-to-day activities relating to the TA.  
The manager, with an appropriate number of support staff, will dedicate a substantial amount of 
time in this role. The manager will submit monthly reports to the steering committee and ADB on 
the progress of the TA. 
 
16.  To ensure proper coordination with the other stakeholders, including those in other 
relevant  Government  agencies,  a  steering  committee  will  be  established.  The  person 
designated as the coordinator of the Supreme Court Steering Committee for Judiciary Reform

5 
 
 
 
 
will head the steering committee for this TA, which will comprise members from the National 
Planning Agency (BAPPENAS); Ministry of Finance; Ministry of Justice; and, as appropriate, a 
non-government  organization  actively  involved  in  the  legal  and  judicial  sector.  The 
representative from each government agency should be a person whose function within the 
agency includes the administering or facilitating the administration of the judiciary. The steering 
committee will meet periodically, at least once a month or more often, if required, to regularly 
review the implementation of the TA. In addition, the committee will also provide general 
guidance and policy direction to the TA manager, to ensure that the output of the TA can be fully 
implemented and replicated in other courts. The steering committee will prepare a report within 
2 months after the completion of the TA, assessing and evaluating the achievements of the TA. 
The report will be submitted to the chief justice of the Supreme Court and ADB.  
 
17.  The TA will require a total of 39 persons-months of consulting services, comprising 9 
person-months of international and 30 person-months of domestic consultancy. An international 
consulting firm will be recruited for the services, in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic 
consultants and using the simplified technical proposal. Quality-and-cost-based selection will be 
used to choose the consulting firm. The consultants should have expertise in case management 
and the implementation of IT in the judiciary. The international consultants will be required to 
work closely with the domestic consultants. One of the international consultants, in association 
with the domestic consultants, will provide the necessary training to the administrative personnel 
in the judiciary. The outline terms of reference of the consultants (which include the consultants 
reporting requirements) are provided in Appendix 3. The consultants will also procure the 
equipment required under the TA using ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. The TA will take 6 
months to implement from the beginning of April 2004 and to the end of September 2004. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia for the Improvement of the Administration of the Supreme Court, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
19.  In order to implement this technical assistance (TA), an international firm in association 
with domestic consultants will be recruited for a total of 39 persons-months: 9 person-months for 
the two international and 30 person-months for the five domestic consultants.  
 
A.   International Consultants  
 
1.  Case Management Expert and Team Leader (6 person-months) 
 
20.  Skills and Requirements. The international consultant dealing with case management 
will be the team leader. The team leader should ideally (i) be an internationally recognized legal 
expert, with previous working experience in managing the judiciary, preferably at the supreme 
court level; (ii) have expertise in applying information technology (IT) and communications in 
courts; (iii) know about management of court cases; (iv) have experience working in Indonesia; 
(v) be familiar with the Indonesian judicial system, and understand the legal reforms being 
undertaken in Indonesia; and (vi) be fluent in English and Bahasa Indonesia. The team leader 
should reside in Indonesia during the implementation of the TA, as intensive interaction will be 
needed with the other consultants and the relevant parties in the Supreme Court. This will 
increase the level of coordination and knowledge sharing among the consultants. 
 
21.  Tasks. The team leader as the case management expert will work closely with the 
domestic consultants to (i) analyze  the current management of case flows in the Supreme 
Court; (ii) assess the effectiveness of the current case-tracking system available in the Supreme 
Court, including its strengths and weaknesses; (iii) prepare a feasibility study on how to improve 
the performance of the current case-tracking system, taking into account the current resources 
available in the Supreme Court; (iv) conduct focus group discussions on the result of the 
feasibility study under point (iii); (v) upgrade the capacity of the existing case-tracking system of 
the Supreme Court; (vi) analyze the cause of the inconsistency in judgments issued by the 
Supreme Court; (vii) assess the strengths and weaknesses of the case classification system in 
the  Supreme  Court;  (viii)  assess  the  effectiveness  of  the  current  chamber  system  in  the 
Supreme Court; (ix) prepare a new  case classification system (to include  sex-disaggregated 
information and gender-based cases); (x) prepare a data base of previous cases to allow links 
between  the  offices  of  the  Supreme  Court  judges;  (xi)  analyze  the  current  process  of 
disseminating Supreme Court judgments, including public accessibility; (xii) prepare a study on 
the best mechanism to allow public access to judgments issued by the Supreme Court; (xiii) 
conduct focus group discussions with stakeholders on the finding of the feasibility study under 
(xii); (xiv) prepare guidelines that will facilitate wider dissemination of and public access to 
judgments issued by the Supreme Court judges; (xv) engage in extensive consultation with the 
Supreme Court officials on the implementation of the guidelines under (xiv); and (xvi) prepare a 
draft decree of the chief justice of the Supreme Court on implementing the guidelines under 
(xiv). 
 
2.  Capacity Building Expert (3 person-months) 
22.  Skills  and  Requirements.  The  expert  will  provide  training  for  the  Supreme  Court 
administrative  personnel  on  managing  cases,  including  the  use  of  IT  solutions  in  case 
management. The expert should ideally (i) be an internationally recognized legal expert with 
practical knowledge about the implementation of management information systems in courts; (ii) 
have experience providing training in the best international practices for case management, 
including the application of IT in the judiciary; (iii) have experience working in Indonesia; (iv) be

familiar with the Indonesian judiciary system and, preferably, understand the legal reforms being 
undertaken in Indonesia; and (v) be fluent in English and Bahasa Indonesia. 
 
23.  The expert will be engaged for 3 person-months on an intermittent basis. The expert will 
work closely with two domestic consultants who also specialize in capacity building. The expert 
should reside in Indonesia for the first and last two months of the TA implementation to allow 
better understanding of the training needs of the Supreme Court and increase the coordination 
and knowledge sharing between the international and domestic consultants.  
 
24.  Tasks. The expert will (i) identify relevant staff at the Supreme Court who require the 
training; (ii) analyze the training needs of the Supreme Court administrative personnel; (iii) 
review  the  best  international  practices  in  the  provision  of  training  for  court  administrative 
personnel and its application to the Supreme Court context; (iv) refine and improve the current 
curricula used by the Education and Training Center of the Supreme Court for training of 
Supreme Court administrative personnel; (v) formulate a training program to support the needs 
of  the  Supreme  Court  administrative  personnel  to  apply  modern  case  management,  with 
emphasis on the application of the IT systems; and (vi) provide appropriate training for the 
Supreme Court administrative personnel in coordination with the Education and Training Center 
of the Supreme Court.  
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
 
1.  Case Administration Specialist (6 person-months) 
25.   The specialist should (i) have a law degree; (ii) be knowledgeable about the operation of 
the judiciary; (iii) have previous experience as a lawyer or a judge; (iv) be proficient in English; 
and (v) have wide access to the Indonesian legal community. The specialist will work closely 
with the international case management expert on the completion of the tasks assigned under 
para. 3 (i) to (v). 
 
2.  Consistent Judgments Specialist (6 person-months) 
26.   The specialist should (i) have a law degree with substantial knowledge in the application 
of  IT  in  the  judiciary;  (ii)  have  the  ability  to  establish  an  automated  data  base;  (iii)  be 
knowledgeable about the operation of the judiciary; and (iv) be proficient in English. The 
specialist will work closely with the international case management expert on the completion of 
the tasks assigned under para. 3 (vi) to (x) 
 
3.  Judgment Dissemination Specialist (6 person-months) 
27.  The specialist should (i) have an IT degree; (ii) have related professional training and 
experience in the IT sector; (iii) understand the application of IT for the judiciary; (iv) know about 
the Indonesian legal system; and (v) be proficient in English. The specialist will work closely with 
the international case management expert on the completion of the tasks assigned under para 3 
(xi) to (xvi).  
 
4.  Two Capacity Building Specialists (6 person-months each) 
28.  Each of the specialists should (i) have a law degree; (ii) know about management 
information systems; (iii) be knowledgeable about the operation of the judiciary system in 
Indonesia;  and  (iv)  be  proficient  in  English.  The  specialists  will  work  closely  with  the

14  Appendix 3 
international capacity-building expert on the completion of the tasks assigned under para. 6(i) to 
(vi). 
 
29.  In  performing  their  duties,  the  consultants  should  take  into  account  (i)  the  best 
international and regional practices; (ii) the need to complement the existing infrastructure 
instead of duplicating it; and (iii) the need to ensure that the system created, including the 
training, will be sustainable. The team leader must ensure that there is strong coordination 
among the consultants recruited. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
 
30.  The consultants will prepare the following reports for the Supreme Court, steering 
committee, and ADB: (i) an inception report, 1 month after TA implementation; (ii) a progress 
report, 3 months after the start of TA implementation; and (iii) a draft final report, 5 months after 
the start of TA implementation. The Supreme Court, steering committee, Asian Development 
Bank, and consultants will hold a coordination meeting to discuss the draft final report. The 
meeting will be held 2 weeks after the submission of the draft final report. The final report, which 
will incorporate the results of the coordination meeting, will be prepared 6 months after the start 
of TA implementation.
